name: @EveryKidinaPark
short_description: A federal initiative to encourage every U.S. 4th grader to explore our great outdoors and history. Follow us on Facebook
long_description:
From the deep seafloor around the Channel Islands to the heights of the Alaska Range, from the Cesar E. Chavez monument in California, to the legacy captured at the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial in Washington D.C., our federal lands and waters should be experienced and enjoyed by every American, especially our youth. 
To ensure continued preservation so the next generation can experience and enjoy all these places have to offer, we must look to a future generation of stewards who can lead the charge. That is why the Every Kid in a Park Initiative is an effort to inspire every child to get outside and learn about the rich history and culture of our nation and the natural wonders of our federal lands and waters.
The Every Kid in a Park initiative grants every 4th grader in the country and their family, free access to these beautiful places for one full year. 
Our federal lands and waters also serve as an innovative resource educators can use to inspire learning in important subjects like history, STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) and the arts and can help make teaching and learning fun. Educators interested in taking advantage of this special teaching and learning opportunity can go to the website to access fun and engaging learning activities, aligned to standard.

name: Hamilton Grange National Memorial
short_description: A founding father’s Harlem home.
long_description: Alexander Hamilton created the tools for the success of the United States. From the humble beginnings as an orphan from the Caribbean island of Nevis, he became George Washington's right hand man. Come visit Hamilton Grange and find out more about this controversial founder and the country home that he built on his Harlem estate.

name: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site
short_description: A National Park site consisting of Theodore Roosevelt's reconstructed childhood home.
long_description: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site, rebuilt shortly after Roosevelt's death, consists of a building designed as two reconstructed townhouses with one reminiscent of Theodore Roosevelt's childhood home and the other recreated as a museum. The building has period rooms containing furniture from the original house as well as extensive exhibits, memorabilia, paintings, a library, and an auditorium. The site is a tribute to Roosevelt and portrays the years of his early life as well as illustrious adult life and career.

name: General Grant National Memorial
short_description: This national memorial is the final resting place of President Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia, and is the largest mausoleum in North America.
long_description: This grand mausoleum testifies to a people’s gratitude for the man who ended the bloodiest conflict in American history as Commanding General of the Union Army and then, as President of the United States, strove to heal a nation after a civil war and make rights for all citizens a reality.

name: Hamilton Grange National Memorial
short_description: This National Park Service site preserves the only home Alexander Hamilton ever owned.
long_description: Alexander Hamilton created the tools for the success of the United States. From the humble beginnings as an orphan from the Caribbean island of Nevis, he became George Washington's right hand man. Come visit Hamilton Grange and find out more about this controversial founder and the country home that he built on his Harlem estate.

name: General Grant National Memorial
short_description: This national memorial is the final resting place of President Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia, and is the largest mausoleum in North America.

name: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site
short_description: This National Park Service site is the boyhood home of Theodore Roosevelt, our 26th president.
long_description: Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site, rebuilt shortly after Roosevelt's death, consists of a building designed as two reconstructed townhouses with one reminiscent of Theodore Roosevelt's childhood home and the other recreated as a museum. The building has period rooms containing furniture from the original house as well as extensive exhibits, memorabilia, paintings, a library, and an auditorium. The site is a tribute to Roosevelt and portrays the years of his early life as well as illustrious adult life and career.

name: NOAA Fisheries New England/Mid-Atlantic
short_description: Stewardship of living marine resources through science-based conservation and management and the promotion of healthy ecosystems.
long_description:
NEFSC plans, develops, and manages a multidisciplinary program of basic and applied research to: (1) better understand living marine resources of the Northeast Continental Shelf Ecosystem from the Gulf of Maine to Cape Hatteras, and the habitat quality essential for their existence and continued productivity; and (2) describe and provide to management, industry, and the public, options for the conservation and utilization of living marine resources, and for the restoration and maintenance of marine environmental quality.

GARFO’s vision is a future in which the American people continue to benefit from a healthy ocean
and coastal ecosystems in the Greater Atlantic Region. Our mission encompasses the stewardship of
living marine and diadromous resources through science-based conservation and management,
focused on protection and restoration of healthy coastal ecosystems. Through this strategic plan,
GARFO’s vision and mission strive for: productive and sustainable fisheries that create and sustain jobs, supporting vibrant fishing
communities, as well as provide opportunities for recreational enjoyment; plentiful domestic sources of seafood; the recovery and conservation of protected resources, and; healthy habitats that support a healthy ecosystem.

name: NOAAFish_NEFSC
short_description: Providing ecosystem-based science to support stewardship of living marine resources under changing climatic conditions.
long_description: NEFSC plans, develops, and manages a multidisciplinary program of basic and applied research to: (1) better understand living marine resources of the Northeast Continental Shelf Ecosystem from the Gulf of Maine to Cape Hatteras, and the habitat quality essential for their existence and continued productivity; and (2) describe and provide to management, industry, and the public, options for the conservation and utilization of living marine resources, and for the restoration and maintenance of marine environmental quality.

name: U.S. Department of the Interior
short_description: The U.S. Department of the Interior is a Cabinet-level agency that manages America's vast natural and cultural resources.
long_description:
The Department of the Interior protects and manages the Nation's natural resources and cultural heritage; provides scientific and other information about those resources; and honors its trust responsibilities or special commitments to American Indians, Alaska Natives, and affiliated island communities. 

The U.S. Department of the Interior is a Cabinet-level agency that manages America's vast natural and cultural resources. The Secretary of the Interior heads our department, which employs 70,000 people, including expert scientists and resource-management professionals, in nine technical bureaus and various offices. The U.S. Department of the Interior protects America's natural resources and heritage, honors our cultures and tribal communities, and supplies the energy to power our future.

NCD utilizes its account to archive community responses to news and report releases and other relevant disability policy information shared utilizing its other social media accounts.

name: NOAA B-WET
short_description: Official Facebook account for the national Bay Watershed Education and Training (B-WET) program managed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
long_description: Official Facebook account for the national Bay Watershed Education and Training program managed by NOAA, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. NOAA's B-WET program funds locally relevant, authentic experiential learning for K-12 audiences through Meaningful Watershed Educational Experiences (MWEEs). MWEEs are multi‐stage activities that include learning both outdoors and in the classroom and aim to increase understanding and stewardship of watersheds and related ocean, coastal, riverine, estuarine, and Great Lakes ecosystems. NOAA funding is provided to support student investigation of environmental topics both locally and globally that are of interest to them, leveraging local STEM assets and STEM professionals.

The Coastal Ecosystem Learning Center (CELC) Network is a consortium of 25 aquariums and marine science education centers located in the United States, Canada, and Mexico. name: USBPChief
short_description: Official twitter account for the Chief of the United States Border Patrol, Chief Rodney Scott.
long_description:
​The United States Border Patrol, headed by the Chief, U.S. Border Patrol, is the primary federal law enforcement organization responsible for preventing the entry of terrorists and their weapons from entering the United States between official U.S. ports of entry. The Border Patrol is also responsible for preventing the illicit trafficking of people and contraband between official ports of entry.

The Border Patrol is specifically responsible for patrolling the 6,000 miles of Mexican and Canadian international land borders and 2,000 miles of coastal waters surrounding the Florida Peninsula and the island of Puerto Rico. Agents work around the clock on assignments, in all types of terrain and weather conditions. Agents also work in many isolated communities throughout the United States.

Today, the Border Patrol has a work force of more than 20,000 agents and 2,000 mission support personnel.

name: U.S. Department of Energy Office of Scientific and Technical Information (OSTI)
short_description: Facebook communications about the Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Scientific and Technical Information (OSTI)
long_description:
Facebook communications about the Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Scientific and Technical Information (OSTI), a unit of the Office of Science, which fulfills agency-wide responsibilities to collect, preserve, and disseminate scientific and technical information (STI) emanating from DOE research and development (R&D) activities. 

OSTI provides access to scientific and technical information related to DOE missions through web-based searchable databases, offering ever-expanding sources of R&D information to DOE, the research community, and the science-attentive public. The OSTI Catalogue of Collections - http://www.osti.gov/home/catalogue-collections - includes DOE science resources, as well as U.S. federal and global science information.

name: USPTO
short_description: The USPTO is a federal agency in the Department of Commerce. The USPTO occupies several interconnected buildings in Alexandria, Virginia. The office employs more than 10,000 people -- including engineers, scientists, attorneys, analysts, computer specialists -- all dedicated to protecting U.S. intellectual property rights.
long_description:
For over 200 years, the basic role of the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) has remained the same: to promote the progress of science and the useful arts by securing for limited times to inventors the exclusive right to their respective discoveries (Article 1, Section 8 of the United States Constitution). Under this system of protection, American industry has flourished. New products have been invented, new uses for old ones discovered, and employment opportunities created for millions of Americans. The strength and vitality of the U.S. economy depends directly on effective mechanisms that protect new ideas and investments in innovation and creativity. The continued demand for patents and trademarks underscores the ingenuity of American inventors and entrepreneurs. The USPTO is at the cutting edge of the Nation’s technological progress and achievement. 

The USPTO is a federal agency in the Department of Commerce. The USPTO occupies several interconnected buildings in Alexandria, Virginia. The office employs more than 10,000 people -- including engineers, scientists, attorneys, analysts, computer specialists -- all dedicated to protecting U.S. intellectual property rights.

name: Peace Corps
short_description: Make the most of your world.
long_description:
Peace Corps is a service opportunity for motivated changemakers to immerse themselves in a community abroad, working side by side with local leaders to tackle the most pressing challenges of our generation.

In 1961, President John F. Kennedy established the Peace Corps to promote world peace and friendship.

The Peace Corps' mission has three simple goals:

1. Helping the people of interested countries in meeting their need for trained men and women.

2. Helping promote a better understanding of Americans on the part of the peoples served.

3. Helping promote a better understanding of other peoples on the part of Americans.

name: U.S. Coast Guard Pacific Northwest
short_description: Welcome to the U.S. Coast Guard Pacific Northwest page on Facebook. If you're looking for the official source of information about the U.S. Coast Guard Pacific Northwest, please visit our homepage at www.uscg.mil/d13
long_description:
This page is intended for use as a two-way communications tool in association with the Coast Guard 13th District Public Affairs Office. Any postings that do not fall in line with the Coast Guard Social Media Policy will be deleted as will the user.

We welcome your comments on postings at all Coast Guard sites/journals. These are sponsored by the U.S. Coast Guard to provide a forum to talk about our work providing maritime safety, security and stewardship for the American people to secure the homeland, save lives and property, protect the environment, and promote economic prosperity.

The information provided is for public information only and is not a distress communication channel. People in an emergency and in need of Coast Guard assistance should use VHF-FM Channel 16 (156.8 MHz), dial 911, or call their nearest Coast Guard unit.

All comments submitted are moderated. The Coast Guard retains the discretion to determine which comments it will post and which it will not. We expect all contributors to be respectful. We will not post comments that contain personal attacks of any kind; refer to Coast Guard or other employees by name; contain offensive terms that target specific ethnic or racial groups, or contain vulgar language. We will also not post comments that are spam, are clearly off topic, or that promote services or products.

The U.S. Coast Guard disclaims any liability for any loss or damage resulting from any comments posted on this page. This forum may not be used for the submission of any claim, demand, informal or formal complaint, or any other form of legal and/or administrative notice or process, or for the exhaustion of any legal and/or administrative remedy.

If you have specific questions regarding a U.S. Coast Guard program that involves details you do not wish to share publicly please contact the program point of contact listed at http://www.uscg.mil/global/mail/

name: Peace Corps Thailand

long_description: Peace Corps Projects in Thailand are governed through a bi-lateral agreement with TICA and specific project agreements with OBEC and DLA. name: Peace Corps Myanmar
short_description: This is Official YouTube Channel for the United States Peace Corps in Myanmar.
long_description:
In early 2013 the Union Government invited Peace Corps to Myanmar. A Country Agreement was concluded and officially announced by President Barack Obama on a visit to Myanmar in November 2014. We collaborate closely with the government and people of Myanmar to meet their needs in the education sector.
The first group of Peace Corps Volunteers arrived in 2016 and began working in an English education assignment. 
Follow us as we establish a wonderful partnership with the people of Myanmar

name: PeaceCropsLiberia
short_description: The Peace Corps traces its roots and mission to 1960, when then Senator John F. Kennedy challenged students at the University of Michigan to serve their country in the cause of peace by living and working in developing countries. From that inspiration grew an agency of the federal government devoted to world peace and friendship.
long_description:
Since that time, 200,000+ Peace Corps Volunteers have served in 139 host countries to work on issues ranging from AIDS education to information technology and environmental preservation.

Today's Peace Corps is more vital than ever, working in emerging and essential areas such as information technology and business development, and contributing to the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief. Peace Corps Volunteers continue to help countless individuals who want to build a better life for themselves, their children, and their communities.

name: Peace Corps The Gambia
short_description: The official page of Peace Corps The Gambia. Make the most of your world. Share your story with #peacecorpsthegambia
long_description:
Since 1967 more than 1,700 Peace Corps Volunteers have served in The Gambia. Currently around 90 volunteers serve in one of three technical sectors: Education, Health, and Environment. Due to the size of The Gambia (it is the smallest country in mainland Africa) volunteers are able to collaborate on many projects, with particularly strong cross-sector initiatives in the areas of Gender-and-Development (GAD) and Food Security.

Peace Corps Volunteers come from diverse backgrounds in the United States. They represent a wide range of ages, religions, and ethnicities, and have vastly differing skills and experience. But they have all come with one thing in common: they want to learn about The Gambia and Gambians and share their skills to effect change.

Almost every Peace Corps Volunteer in The Gambia lives with a host family in a mud or concrete block compound. This proximity, sharing meals and becoming part of a family, helps volunteers to learn Gambian culture and language and to develop close ties to their communities – an integral factor in the development work that they undertake.

Take a look at some of the projects we’re involved in – we’ll update our Facebook page with stories, pictures, news articles, and Peace Corps events. Like the page if you’d like to keep up with the work that we do here.

name: U.S. Coast Guard Sector North Bend
short_description: Welcome to the U.S. Coast Guard Sector North Bend Facebook page. For the official source of information about the US Coast Guard, visit www.uscg.mil
long_description:
Sector North Bend is co-located with Air Station North Bend in the Port of Coos Bay, OR. Working hand in hand with the Sector’s six Motor Life Boat Stations, the Coast Guard Cutter Orcas, and Coos Bay Aids to Navigation (ANT) team, the Air Station’s crews stand a 24/7 watch protecting those at sea and inland.

Although beautiful, the rugged Oregon coast can become dangerous at a moment’s notice. Notoriously strong winds, powerful waves in excess of 40 feet, unpredictable fog, blinding rain, steep cliffs, remote mountains, and thousands of miles of rivers create unique challenges for our helicopter and boat crews. From inland mountain rescues of injured loggers and hikers, to at sea search and rescue cases of sinking vessels or lost fishermen, the members of Sector North Bend stand a vigilant watch no matter the conditions.

Sector North Bend protects the environment with the clear understanding that the quality of people's lives and livelihoods depend on diligent stewardship of our nation's maritime resources. All of our missions are accomplished through vigilance, tenacity, teamwork, a commitment to service, community, and the unwavering pursuit of operational excellence.

name: U.S. Coast Guard Station Coos Bay
short_description: Welcome to the U.S. Coast Guard Station Coos Bay page. For the official source of information about the U. S. Coast Guard, please visit www.uscg.mil
long_description: In 1878, the first life-saving station, later to become a Coast Guard station, was located at Cape Arago below the lighthouse on a small sandy beach. It was a simple structure manned by a single keeper and sparsely equipped. In case of an emergency, the keeper had to rouse a volunteer crew before any rescue attempt. In 1892, Station Coos Bay was moved from the lighthouse to the North Spit of Coos Bay and was a fully manned station. The station moved again in 1915. This time it moved from the North Spit to the lee side of Coos Head promontory. A larger station was built consisting of a main administration building and quarters, a boathouse, a workshop and one house reserved for the officerin charge. The last move for Station Coos Bay was in 1968, to its present location at Charleston Boat Basin.

short_description: AmeriCorps brings people together to serve communities. AmeriCorps NCCC (National Civilian Community Corps) and NCCC FEMA Corps are national service programs for ages 18-26. Join us to make a difference, gain new skills and earn money for college. If you are looking for more information about AmeriCorps NCCC, please visit: www.AmeriCorps.Gov/NCCC.
long_description: AmeriCorps NCCC (National Civilian Community Corps) is a full-time service program that covers lodging and travel expenses, allowing young adults to serve on a team and make an impact in communities across the country while gaining valuable leadership skills. Over ten months, AmeriCorps NCCC members work full-time on several projects, from building and rehabilitating homes for families in need to cleaning up parks, streams, trails, and shorelines to helping communities recover from disasters. FEMA Corps is a newer track of NCCC, where members focus solely on disaster response and recovery activities with FEMA. Throughout their twelve month term, members provide support that ranges from working directly with disaster survivors to supporting disaster recovery centers to sharing valuable disaster mitigation and recovery information with the public. AmeriCorps NCCC and FEMA Corps members are assigned to one of four campuses located across the country: Sacramento, CA; Aurora, CO; Vinton, IA; or Vicksburg, MS. If you are looking for more information about AmeriCorps NCCC, please visit: www.AmeriCorps.Gov/NCCC.

name: Peace Corps Togo
short_description: Peace Corps Togo is a governmental organization committed to promoting peace and cultural exchange between the Togolese people and American citizens.
long_description: The Peace Corps began its work in Togo in 1962, as part of the second wave of countries where the Peace Corps began service. Since that time, more than 2,880 Volunteers have served in Togo. The Peace Corps in Togo has a successful history of collaboration and involvement with the Togolese people at all levels. The Volunteers’ efforts build upon counterpart relationships and emphasize low-cost solutions that make maximum use of local resources, which are usually people. Collaboration with local and international private organizations, as well as international development organizations, is an important component of Volunteer project activities.

long_description: AmeriCorps, a federal agency, brings people together to tackle the country’s most pressing challenges, through national service and volunteering. AmeriCorps engages approximately 75,000 men and women in intensive service each year at more than 21,000 locations across the country. By bringing people together to serve communities, AmeriCorps is making service to others an indispensable part of the American experience. Learn more at AmeriCorps.gov

name: Peace Corps Uganda
short_description: Peace Corps Uganda page is set up for communication purposes. This is a place were Peace Corps Volunteer's in Uganda or coming to the country can receive information, feedback and resources on their service.
long_description:
COMMENT POLICY
Peace Corps welcomes your courteous contributions. However, please remember that you are fully responsible for the content of your comments.
To keep this page in the spirit of peace and friendship, we reserve the right to delete comments that include any of the following:
*Violent, obscene, profane, hateful, or racist comments
*Threats or defamatory statements against any person or organization
*Solicitations, advertisements, or endorsements of any financial, commercial or non-governmental entities
*Comments that suggest or encourage illegal activity
*Excessive off-topic posts by a single user
*Repetitive posts copied and pasted by multiple users
*Any other content that Peace Corps may deem inappropriate

If you have any questions or comments about this policy, please email us at info@ug.peacecorps.gov

name: Peace Corps Cambodia
short_description: Peace Corps Volunteers' life in Cambodia
long_description:
Peace Corps welcomed their first group of Volunteers in Cambodia in 2007. Since then, 330 Volunteers have served in 15 of Cambodia’s 24 provinces. All our Volunteers live with host families during pre-service training and throughout their two years of service. Living with a family helps our Volunteers integrate into the communities in which they work, study local culture and traditions, and learn to speak Khmer.

Peace Corps Cambodia currently has two technical projects: English Teaching and Teacher Training, which started in 2007, and Community Health Education, which launched in 2010. Please contact us if your school or health center is interested in working with one of our Volunteers. 

Volunteers join the Peace Corps from every walk of life and represent the diversity of the United States. They can be any age, religion, or ethnicity and may come to the Cambodia with vastly different skills and experience. They join for different reasons: to gain work experience, to share their skills, to learn about the world, and to make a positive difference. But they have one thing in common: a sincere desire to learn about Cambodia and Cambodians.

We invite you to experience a sampling of the great work our Volunteers are doing through the posts on this page. You will find an assortment of stories, project descriptions, Volunteer blogs, and press releases highlighting just a few of our Volunteers in action, as they carry out the first, second, and third goals of Peace Corps.

name: Peace Corps Jamaica
short_description: To create a more safe, secure and pro-development environment for Volunteers to serve by raising awareness of the 3 Goals of Peace Corps.
long_description:
-To share high-quality Video Story monthly to promote greater understanding on the part of Jamaicans and Americans of the work that PCVs and their counterparts do in Jamaica.

- To share Jamaican culture. 

- To expand the number of applications for PCVs from potential host country project partners by 15% by increasing awareness of PCJ’s presence and role.

- To empower, validate and support current PCVs by sharing their work with other PCVs, Prospective PCVs, and other members of our audience as determined by a post-created survey. 

-To use the channel to host 4 podcast episodes per year that will highlight PCV development stories.

name: 123AWKY
short_description: This page features the latest news, photos and videos showcasing the mission and members of the 123rd Airlift Wing.
long_description:
Based at Louisville International Airport in Louisville, Ky., the 123rd Airlift Wing performs a variety of key Air Force missions, including intra-theater airlift, contingency response, explosive ordnance disposal, combat control, and special tactics search and rescue.

 As a component of the Kentucky National Guard, the wing also serves the Commonwealth of Kentucky, providing disaster-response capability and other essential services as directed by the governor.

 The wing currently flies eight C-130H Hercules aircraft and has approximately 1,200 members.

 For more information, including a full index of internal news coverage, photos, fact sheets, leadership biographies and unit history, please visit our official Web site, www.123aw.ang.af.mil.

 For more information on joining the 123rd Airlift Wing, please call the recruiting office at (502) 413-4222 or visit http://www.goang.com/.

name: Peace Corps Namibia
short_description: The official page for Peace Corps Namibia. The page is managed and updated by the Peace Corps Namibia Media Committee.
long_description:
PEACE CORPS NAMIBIA

There are 143 Volunteers in Namibia working with their communities on projects in community economic development, education, and health. During their service in Namibia, Volunteers learn to speak local languages, including Afrikaans, Damara, Khoekhoegowab, Oshikwanyama, Oshindonga, Otijherero, Rukwangali, and Silozi. More than 1,575 Peace Corps Volunteers have served in Namibia since the program was established in 1990.

name: Peace Corps Ghana
short_description: Welcome to Peace Corps Ghana. In August of 1961, Ghana became the first country in the world to receive Peace Corps Volunteers. After nearly 54 years of uninterrupted collaboration, we have roughly 130 Volunteers serving in all 10 regions of the country, at any given time. Our volunteers generally serve in three capacity building sectors: health, education and agriculture.
long_description:
Welcome to Peace Corps Ghana. In August of 1961, Ghana became the first country in the world to receive Peace Corps Volunteers. After nearly 54 years of uninterrupted collaboration, we have roughly 130 Volunteers serving in all 10 regions of the country, at any given time. Our volunteers generally serve in three capacity building sectors: health, education and agriculture. Additionally, the majority of our volunteers work in one or more of the following cross-sector initiatives: HIV/AIDS Awareness & Prevention; Food Security; and Gender & Youth Development.

The goals of Peace Corps Ghana are to promote sustainable development, and to build mutual cultural understanding on the part of Americans and Ghanaians. We achieve these goals by encouraging our volunteers to work with community members to address issues in ways that are sensitive to the cultural values and consistent with the available resources of their communities. Our volunteers supplement host country efforts, they do not serve as a substitute for those efforts. Our volunteers work with an aim of reducing dependency through achievement of developmental goals defined by the Ghanaian government.

We believe that "development" is a learning process, in which the people involved are developing skills, know-how, confidence, and the ability to identify and address issues that affect them on a daily basis. Peace Corps Ghana is proud of the role that we have played in Ghana’s development as an independent nation. We look forward to remaining an active partner with Ghana as she strives towards achieving "middle income country" status by 2020.

name: PCV Media
short_description: Peace Corps Ghana and PCV Media would like to share our high-quality material filmed and produced by Peace Corps Volunteers to educate and inspire.
long_description:
Peace Corps Ghana and PCV Media would like to share our high-quality material filmed and produced by Peace Corps Volunteers to educate and inspire.

Mission
In 1961, President John F. Kennedy established the Peace Corps to promote world peace and friendship.

The Peace Corps' mission has three simple goals:

1. Helping the people of interested countries in meeting their need for trained men and women.

2. Helping promote a better understanding of Americans on the part of the peoples served.

3. Helping promote a better understanding of other peoples on the part of Americans.

name: USGS Natural Hazards Science
short_description: Discussion and information related to natural hazards that the USGS researches.
long_description:
Every year in the United States, natural hazards threaten lives and livelihoods and result in billions of dollars in damage. We work with many partners to monitor, assess, and conduct targeted research on a wide range of natural hazards so that policymakers and the public have the understanding they need to enhance preparedness, response, and resilience.

The USGS provides alerts and warnings of geologic hazards and supports the warning responsibilities of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) for geomagnetic storms, tsunamis, and volcanic ash. This page is promoted by the USGS Natural Hazards Mission Area, which consists of the following programs:

Coastal and Marine Geology
Earthquake Hazards
Geomagnetism
Global Seismographic Network
Landslide Hazards
Volcano Hazards
Emergency Management

long_description: The National Cryptologic Museum (NCM) is the first and only fully public museum in the Intelligence Community. The NCM's Facebook page is an extension of the physical facility. It allows thousands of people from around the world to explore our artifacts and learn more about key events and men and women in cryptologic history. The Facebook page also informs viewers about events held at the museum so they can stay abreast of educational programs.

name: U.S. Coast Guard HC27J APO Elizabeth City NC
short_description: Regeneration and missionization of HC-27J Spartan aircraft to support a variety of Coast Guard missions.
long_description: The mission of the HC-27J Asset Project Office is to provide regeneration, training and performance support, supply and logistics, and missionization to the U.S. Coast Guard through the acquisition lifecycle of the aircraft. There are currently 14 HC-27J Spartan aircraft in the Coast Guard inventory, with six stationed at Air Station Sacramento, two in the depot maintenance process at the Aviation Logistics Center, Elizabeth City, and five at the project office. The final aircraft is completing the regeneration process at an Air Force facility in Tucson, Arizona.

name: NOAA Office of Ocean Exploration and Research-Education
short_description: This Facebook account provides teachers with exploration-focused, standards-based tips and tools to bring the excitement and science of ocean exploration into your classroom.
long_description: NOAA’s Office of Ocean Exploration and Research (OER) –Education Facebook account shares educational resources and services with formal and informal educators and students. The Facebook account will highlight timely and classroom-relevant ocean exploration/NOAA educational resources, including engaging imagery and multimedia tools, as well as OER onsite and online professional development opportunities held at aquariums and science centers around the country. This effort will increase the reach and visibility of OER Education within the education community, thus helping to fulfill OER’s strategic goal of enhancing ocean literacy and inspiring the next generation of ocean explorers, scientists and engineers.

name: NOAA Office of Ocean Exploration and Research
short_description: Instagram account highlighting images collected during mission to explore the deep ocean, funded by the NOAA Office of Ocean Exploration and Research.
long_description: The NOAA Office of Ocean Exploration and Research is the only U.S. federal organization dedicated to exploring the global ocean, filling critical gaps in the basic understanding of U.S. deep waters and seafloor. This Instagram account highlights images from current and past missions to explore the deep ocean, both by NOAA and partners. Posts also include links for more info, to allow users to follow the excitement -- and understand the value of -- ocean exploration.

short_description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency ensures a safe and sound national banking system for all Americans.
long_description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) charters, regulates, and supervises all national banks and federal savings associations. The OCC also supervises the federal branches and agencies of foreign banks. Our goal in supervising banks and federal savings associations is to ensure that they operate in a safe and sound manner and in compliance with laws requiring fair treatment of their customers and fair access to credit and financial products.

name: Southeast Louisiana National Wildlife Refuges Complex
short_description: Southeast Louisiana National Wildlife Refuges Complex Facebook
long_description: The eight National Wildlife Refuges of the Southeast Louisiana complex are part of a coastal wetlands system that includes marshes, pine and bottomland hardwood forests, lakes, barrier islands, swamps and bayous. The diversity of wildlife found on these refuges is representative of Louisiana’s natural ecosystem. The eight National Wildlife Refuges include Atchafalaya, Bayou Sauvage, Bayou Teche, Big Branch Marsh, Bogue.

name: Office of Inspector General, Federal Reserve Board and Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
short_description: Trusted oversight of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
long_description:
We provide independent oversight of two federal agencies:
     •  The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System 
     •  The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau 
Our mission: improve the economy, efficiency, and effectiveness of their programs and operations and prevent and detect fraud, waste, and abuse.

Our audits and evaluations assess the agencies’ programs and operations, including their supervision of financial institutions, their compliance with laws and regulations, and their internal operations. Our reports explain why we conducted the review, what issues we found, and how the agency can correct them. 

In addition, we investigate wrongdoing by agency employees, contractors, or any person or entity related to the agencies’ programs and operations. We also investigate wrongdoing that hinders the agencies’ ability to supervise financial institutions within their jurisdictions—for example, if a bank provides false information to agency regulators. If you have any information about such wrongdoing, visit our website to file a report with our hotline at https://oig.federalreserve.gov/hotline.htm.

short_description: NPS site for Golden Spike National Historic Site.
long_description: Golden Spike National Historic Site is dedicated to the completion of our nation's first transcontinental railroad. The site features a visitor center, two driving tours, a hiking trail, and two fully functional steam powered locomotives that operate from May 1st to Columbus Day. During the winter months the locomotives are on display in the Engine House while they undergo maintenance in preparation for the summer season.

name: NINDS Brain For Life
short_description: On this page, you can learn the signs of stroke and the importance of receiving immediate medical treatment during a stroke. You can also learn about the connection between high blood pressure, stroke, and dementia; and migraines in teens.
long_description:
At the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS), our mission is to seek fundamental knowledge about the brain and nervous system and to use that knowledge to reduce the burden of neurological disease. What makes cells in one part of the brain more likely to get damaged than cells in other areas? When brain cells are talking to one another, can we listen in on the conversation? Is it possible to treat, or prevent neurological disorders? At NINDS, we look at all aspects of brain science, from the molecular building blocks that form brain cells and their connections to the effectiveness of a treatment on hundreds of people suffering from a neurological disease.

That’s where Brain for Life comes in. We want to serve as your one-stop shop for information on the brain and nervous system.

name: NINDSnews
short_description: Official Twitter account of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke
long_description:
The mission of NINDS is to seek fundamental knowledge about the brain and nervous system and to use that knowledge to reduce the burden of neurological disease.

To support this mission, NINDS:

Supports and performs basic, translational, and clinical neuroscience research through grants-in-aid, contracts, scientific meetings, and through research in its own laboratories, and clinics.
Funds and conducts research training and career development programs to increase basic, translational and clinical neuroscience expertise and ensure a vibrant, talented, and diverse work force.
Promotes the timely dissemination of scientific discoveries and their implications for neurological health to the public, health professionals, researchers, and policy-makers.

name: NIH/NINDS Countermeasures Against Chemical Threats (CounterACT) Program
short_description: This group is comprised of researchers (to include past, present, and hopefully future members of the CounterACT program) interested in the field of medical countermeasure research and development to enhance the nation's medical response capabilities during a chemical emergency.
long_description:
In 2006 the National Institute of Health (NIH) developed the Countermeasures Against Chemical Threats (CounterACT) Research Grant Program to foster the research and development of new and improved therapeutics to reduce mortality and morbidity during and/or after civilian chemical emergency events. To date, there has been considerable progress in the areas of target identification, hit and lead development, and preclinical studies. Investigators have identified several molecular entities that show promise as novel targets for therapeutic discovery and development. In vitro and in vivo models for screening are being developed and validated against human and animal efficacy studies. These models have produced several novel compounds with biological activity that is now being tested in proof-of-principle studies with more advanced animal models. There has also been progress in developing new indications for several FDA-approved drugs. Investigators have published over 800 articles in some of the most prestigious peer-reviewed journals in science, including reports of important discoveries that have implications beyond chemical defense. Over a half dozen compounds have been identified as lead compounds, and several meetings (pre-IND, IND, and NDA) with the FDA have already occurred. One drug is poised for possible FDA approval and government procurement for the SNS very soon. 

See http://www.ninds.nih.gov/counteract for specific aspects of the NIH CounterACT portfolio, possible avenues for fruitful collaborations, and active funding opportunity announcements

name: NIH Epilepsy Program
short_description: NIH conducts epilepsy research at our labs and clinics in Bethesda, MD and also supports research by scientists at institutions across the US
long_description: NIH Epilepsy is a collaborative effort of the NIH intramural and extramural programs. The NIH is made up of 27 institutes and centers, each with a specific research agenda, often focusing on particular diseases or body systems. NIH Epilepsy is part of one of those institutes, the National Institute of Neurologic Diseases and Stroke (NINDS). NINDS supports clinical, translational and basic research related to epilepsy at the NIH Clinical Center and around the world.

short_description: Government Education Organization in Pensacola, Florida
long_description: The Defense Activity for Non-Traditional Education Support (DANTES) administers programs and services supporting the voluntary education (VolEd) functions of the Office of the Secretary of Defense, including the Military Services, Reserves, and other Department of Defense (DoD) components. DANTES' mission is to provide high-quality, valuable educational information and opportunities to service members and their families, as well as DoD personnel.

name: Troops to Teachers - DANTES/DoD
short_description: Government Organization in Pensacola, Florida
long_description:
Troops to Teachers was established in 1993 to assist transitioning service members and veterans in beginning new careers as K-12 teachers in public, charter, and Bureau of Indian Affairs schools. 

The program provides counseling, employment facilitation, and financial support services for eligible participants to help them meet education and licensing requirements to teach and subsequently secure employment as a teacher. Since 1993, more than 20,000 veterans have successfully transitioned to a career in education.

name: DANTES_DoD
short_description: The Defense Activity for Non-Traditional Education Support (DANTES) helps service members and veterans pursue their educational goals and earn degrees.
long_description: The Defense Activity for Non-Traditional Education Support (DANTES) helps Service members and Veterans pursue their educational goals and earn degrees or certifications both during and after their service. DANTES is a Department of Defense component of the Defense Human Resources Activity (DHRA) that provides leadership and support for this important effort through partnerships across the education community.

name: TTT_DANTES
short_description: TTT assists transitioning service members with meeting the requirements necessary to become teachers in K-12 public, charter & Bureau of Indian Affairs schools.
long_description: Troops to Teachers was established in 1993 to assist transitioning Service members and veterans in beginning new careers as K-12 school teachers in public, charter, and Bureau of Indian Affairs schools. The program provides counseling and referral services for participants to help them meet education and licensing requirements to teach and subsequently helps them secure a teaching position. Since 1993, more than 20,000 veterans have successfully transitioned to a career in education.

name: Troops to Teachers - DANTES/DoD
short_description: The mission of Troops to Teachers is to assist transitioning service members and veterans with meeting the requirements necessary to become teachers and to assist program participants with finding employment as a teacher when eligible.
long_description:
BECOME A TEACHER! Service members interested in a career in teaching will receive assistance to transition their leadership skills, training and core values to teaching in K - Grade 12 schools. Veterans bring the values of service to country and community to the classroom and help to shape the future of the country by inspiring its young minds.  

The mission of Troops to Teachers is to assist transitioning service members and veterans with meeting the requirements necessary to become teachers and to assist program participants with finding employment as a teacher when eligible.

name: DANTES - Defense Activity for Non-Traditional Education Support
short_description: The Defense Activity for Non-Traditional Education Support (DANTES), a component of the Defense Human Resource Activity (DoD), helps service members and veterans pursue their educational goals, earn degrees and certifications, and prepare for transition to the civilian workforce.
long_description:
The Defense Activity for Non-Traditional Education Support (DANTES), a component of the Defense Human Resource Activity (DoD), helps service members and veterans pursue their educational goals, earn degrees and certifications, and prepare for transition to the civilian workforce.

Established in 1974, DANTES creates, directs, and markets voluntary education programs and services designed to enrich the academic and career development of service members across the Department of Defense and Coast Guard, to include their family members. By fostering strategic partnerships, DANTES provides program and contract management activities that enable nearly 300,000 service members to prepare for military advancement, officer accession programs, postsecondary degree completion and civilian career transition each year.

short_description: Official account for training & career-related news from NIGMS. Privacy policy http://bit.ly/2jnhHvZ  & disclaimers http://bit.ly/2kGSdGM .
long_description:
Thank you for visiting the @NIGMStraining Link to an external website​​​ twitter feed. This feed is designed to provide training and career-related news from the NIGMS Division of Training, Workforce Development, and Diversity (TWD) and the Center for Research Capacity Building (CRCB). You can find more about each of them below:

Training, Workforce Development & Diversity
NIGMS supports programs that foster research training and the development of a strong and diverse biomedical research workforce through a variety of programs at the undergraduate, graduate, postdoctoral and faculty levels.

Center for Research Capacity Building
The Center for Research Capacity Building (CRCB) supports research, research training, faculty development, and research infrastructure improvements in states that historically have not received significant levels of research funding from NIH. It also supports faculty research development at institutions that have a historical mission focused on serving students from underrepresented groups, research and research capacity building directed by Native American and Alaska Native tribal organizations, and conducts a science education program designed to improve life-science literacy.

name: USDA Forest Service Alaska Region
short_description: USFS Region 10
long_description:
Alaska contains 17 percent of all U.S. Forest Service lands and contains the two largest forests in the nation. The Tongass National Forest stretches over the 500-mile-long Southeast Alaska Panhandle and covers over 80 percent of that land. The Chugach National Forest makes a 210-mile arc around Prince William Sound.
 
We invite you to explore the nation’s two single largest national forests – the Chugach and Tongass, located in south-central and southeast Alaska. From the Chugach and the famous Russian River of the Kenai Peninsula to the Tongass, which covers most of Southeast Alaska, surrounding the famous Inside Passage, the Alaska Region offers amazing diversity and the most beautiful, famous and stunning forests in the nation.
 
This region offers unique chances to view eagles, bears, spawning salmon and breath-taking vistas of "wild" Alaska. As a place for individuals and families to enjoy the outdoors you can take a sled-dog ride on a glacier, hike boardwalk trails, fish in streams or ocean, or just relax at a remote cabin. These special areas offer the ability to escape the crowds of the city and encounter nature at its best.

short_description: The official Facebook page of Peace Corps Eastern Caribbean
long_description:
About
The Peace Corps entered the Eastern Caribbean in 1961, when St. Lucia became one of the first three countries in the world to receive Volunteers. Since then, approximately 3,800 Peace Corps Volunteers have served on 10 island nations in the region.

General Information
***This is the official page of Peace Corps Eastern Caribbean***

COMMENT POLICY
Peace Corps welcomes your courteous contributions. However, please remember that you are fully responsible for the content of your comments.

To keep this page in the spirit of peace and friendship, we reserve the right to delete comments that include any of the following:

*Violent, obscene, profane, hateful, or racist comments

*Threats or defamatory statements against any person or organization

*Solicitations, advertisements, or endorsements of any financial, commercial or non-governmental entities

*Comments that suggest or encourage illegal activity

*Excessive off-topic posts by a single user

*Repetitive posts copied and pasted by multiple users

*Any other content that Peace Corps may deem inappropriate

name: BIA Forestry and Wildland Fire Management
short_description: BIAFireForestry
long_description:
The Division of Forestry and Wildland Fire Management (DFWFM) is responsible for providing coordination, management, planning, oversight, and monitoring for all activities related to development and protection of trust forest resources on nearly 18 million acres of forest land. In addition, the National Wildland Fire Program has protection responsibility on about 60 million acres of trust and non-trust land.

DFWFM exercises program oversight and provides planning and scheduling of Bureau-wide forestry activities at the national level to ensure that regulatory and policy requirements are followed and that technical standards of sound forest management are upheld.

The division has staff in Washington, DC; Denver, Colorado; the National Interagency Fire Center in Boise, Idaho; and interagency fire coordination centers in Missoula, Montana; and Albuquerque, New Mexico.

name: BIA Forestry & Wildland Fire - Mescallero Agency
short_description: BIAMescalleroForestry.Fire
long_description:
The commercial forest base is managed on a 20- year cutting cycle with approximately 7,500 acres being harvested each year with an average harvest level of 2,240 board feet per acre. Even-aged and uneven-aged silvicultural systems are used on the reservation with uneven-aged management being the preferred method. Dwarf mistletoe infection levels are quite high and periodic insect infestations are also common. Post-harvest follow-up treatments, timber stand improvement operations, and reforestation efforts are conducted by the Tribe’s Division of Resource Management and Protection.

There is an active woodland management program on the reservation. Watershed restoration surrounding the community of Mescalero and pinyon juniper savannah restoration on the east side of the reservation have been the most recent focus projects. Fuels reduction operations and prescribed burning are conducted on over 5,000 acres yearly in joint efforts between the Bureau’s Fire Management Section and the Tribe’s Division of Resource Management and Protection.

The Standing Rock Sioux Indian Reservation straddles North and South Dakota and encompasses all of Sioux County in North and all of Corson County, and small parcels in Ziebach and Perkins Counties in South Dakota.

name: BIA Forestry & Fire Management - Southern Plains Region
short_description: The Division provides services related to planning, coordination, and evaluating programs in the fields of Natural Resources, Forestry and Wildland Fire Management while providing assistance to protect and enhance the value of Indian Trust assets.
long_description:
The Southern Plains Region encompasses a dynamic and diverse mix of Tribes, Tribal members and natural resources. Of the nearly 90,000 Tribal members that make up the 24 Tribes under the Southern Plains jurisdiction, 55,000 live within the three State service areas, which stretch from the Texas/Mexico border, across West central Oklahoma before finally ending in Northern Kansas.
Within that area the Southern Plains Regional Office (SPRO) is located in Anadarko, Oklahoma as is the Anadarko Agency. The additional three agencies under the SPRO are the Pawnee Agency located in Pawnee, Oklahoma, the Concho Agency located in El Reno, Oklahoma, and the Horton Agency located in Horton, Kansas. The service area is comprised of 585,000 acres of Trust property contained within 13,000 highly fractionated tracts. This high fractionation makes for a challenging work environment at the Regional Office and the individual Agencies.
The following tribes are serviced under the Southern Plains Regional Office:
Alabama-Coushatta Tribe - Located in Livingston, Texas with 993 enrolled members
Kickapoo Traditional Tribe - Located in Eagle Pass, Texas with 880 enrolled members
Absentee Shawnee Tribe - Located in Shawnee, Oklahoma with 2,926 enrolled members
Citizen Potawatomi Nation - Located in Shawnee, Oklahoma with 23,557 enrolled members
Delaware Nation of Western OK - Located in Anadarko, Oklahoma with 1,302 enrolled members
Kaw Nation - Located in Kaw City, Oklahoma with 2,553 enrolled members
Kickapoo Tribe - Located in McLoud, Oklahoma with 2,505 enrolled members
Sac and Fox Nation - Located in Stroud, Oklahoma with 3,025 enrolled members
Branch of Natural Resources, Division of Wildland Fire Management
The Division provides services related to planning, coordination, and evaluating programs in the fields of Natural Resources, Forestry and Wildland Fire Management while providing assistance to protect and enhance the value of Indian Trust assets. Emphasis is placed on improving these resources through hazardous fuels reduction, Reserved Treaty Rights Lands projects, and assisting agricultural programs through prescribed burning. While hazardous fuels removal (Eastern Red Cedar eradication) is the main driver, the Wildland Fire Management program provides suppression resources for local wildland fires and supports Oklahoma Forestry Service, Volunteer Fire Departments, Tribal Departments, and other Federal Interagency Partners within the State.

name: BIA Forestry & Wildland Fire Management - Umatilla Agency
short_description: @UmatillaAgencyFireMgt
long_description:
The Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation is a union of three tribes:  Cayuse, Umatilla, and Walla Walla. There are over 3,100 tribal members, nearly half of which live on or near the Umatilla Reservation. The Reservation is also home to another 300 Indians who are members of other tribes.  About 1,500 non-Indians also live on the Reservation.  
The Reservation is about about 273 square miles. In 1855 the three tribes signed a treaty with the US government, in which it ceded over 6.4 million acres to the United States.  In the treaty, the tribes reserved rights to fish, hunt, and gather foods and medicines within the ceded lands, which today is northeastern Oregon and southeastern Washington.  Tribal members still exercise and protect those rights today.

name: BIA Forestry & Wildland Fire Management - Ramah Navajo & Zuni Agencies
short_description: The Ramah Navajo & Zuni Agency became a Zoned Fire Program in 2013. Fire management staff provide fire protection services for both Zuni and Ramah Navajo Reservations.
long_description:
The Ramah Navajo & Zuni Agency became a zoned fire management program in 2013. Fire response resources provide services across 979,364 acres. While two Superintendents administrate each agency, the Fire Management Officer manages the fire management programs within the zone. 
Within the Fire Management Program, there are five Model 52 Type 6 engines, a wildfire prevention program, fuels program, and a 4th tier dispatch office. Zuni is also the home for the Type 1 Hotshot Crew- Zuni IHC. Both agencies recruit and maintain type 2 initial attack crews and camp crews that are filled by emergency firefighters that are called when needed. 
In addition to providing initial attack services to the Reservations, they also support their neighboring partners each season with engine modules, a 10 person initial attack hand crew and other well-qualified firefighters.  
 Zuni Agency also has a forestry program, which is managed by the agency forester.

name: Peace Corps Fiji
short_description: This page is used to support Peace Corps Fiji
long_description:
This page will promote the diverse and vast experiences of Peace Corps Volunteers to both prospective Volunteers, host country nationals, and returned peace corps Volunteers.

Introduction: 

Peace Corps Fiji’s social media accounts will promote the goals of Peace Corps. The accounts will raise awareness and increase support to Peace Corps Fiji (PC Fiji) and its activities.

The accounts would be used to: 
•	Recruit prospective Volunteers 
•	Spotlight accomplishments of Peace Corps Volunteers (PCVs) and the Post’s country program
•	Inform Host Country Nationals (HCNs) of the work of Peace Corps Fiji (PC-Fiji) and program activities
•	Promote local activities and programs relevant to PC Fiji’s work


Audience:

More than 70 percent of Peacecorps.gov’s visitors self-identify as prospective Volunteers.  Our social media content will cater primarily to this audience in addition to current Volunteers, returned Volunteers, family and friends, partner organizations, and HCNs.  This social media presence, while focusing strongly on recruitment messaging, will also seek to reach these additional audiences when creating and posting content, as well as to provide a broader prospective of PC Fiji’s activities.  


Content:

In order to maximize viewership, multiple social media applications will be used.  An ongoing effort will be made to represent the diversity of and within the Agency, Fiji culture and its Volunteers.

long_description: Our mission is to provide high quality base operations and community support to all U.S. personnel in Grafenwoehr-Vilseck, Hohenfels and Garmisch. We directly support the 7th Army Joint Multinational Training Command (JMTC), the largest training command outside the continental United States, the Combat Maneuver Training Command, 172nd Infantry Brigade, 2nd Cavalry Regiment and many other tenant units. We also support the American Embassy in Berlin and its consulate in Munich.

name: Maine Coastal Island National Wildlife Refuge
short_description: The Maine Coastal Islands National Wildlife Refuge Complex
long_description:
The Maine Coastal Islands National Wildlife Refuge Complex is comprised of five individual refuges which span the coast of Maine and support an incredible diversity of habitats including coastal islands, forested headlands, estuaries and freshwater wetlands. All totaled, the refuge includes approximately 8,238 acres of diverse coastal Maine habitats including forested and non-forested offshore islands, coastal salt marsh, open field, and upland mature spruce-fir forest.
Audience you are trying to reach: General public, tourist, other conservation groups in our area.

Through our officers and other employees, we work to make the criminal justice process effective and the public safe.

long_description:

name: Defense Acquisition University
short_description: Training provider for the DoD Acquisition Workforce
long_description: DAU provides a full range of basic, intermediate, and advanced certification training; assignment specific training; continuous learning modules; rapid deployment training; knowledge sharing resources; job support tools; mission assistance; workshops; and job-relevant applied research. We believe it is our duty to deliver quality products and services in the most effective and efficient way. Our efforts develop a qualified acquisition workforce through foundational learning, workflow learning, and performance learning, which, when combined, result in more successful acquisition outcomes. As an inherently governmental resource, only DAU has the combined attributes of being a steward of the acquisition body of knowledge, staffed with government expert practitioners, accredited and recognized world-wide for excellence, and possessing a strong trusted relationship with senior DoD leadership and Congress.

Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
short_description: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency YouTube
long_description:
The OCC charters, regulates, and supervises all national banks and federal savings associations as well as federal branches and agencies of foreign banks. The OCC is an independent bureau of the U.S. Department of the Treasury.

Mission

To ensure that national banks and federal savings associations operate in a safe and sound manner, provide fair access to financial services, treat customers fairly, and comply with applicable laws and regulations.

Vision

The OCC is a preeminent prudential supervisor that
•adds value through proactive and risk-based supervision;
•is sought after as a source of knowledge and expertise; and
•promotes a vibrant and diverse banking system that benefits consumers, communities, businesses, and the U.S. economy.

Core Values
•Integrity
•Expertise
•Collaboration
•Independence

name: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency Facebook
short_description: The OCC's primary mission is to charter, regulate, and supervise all national banks and federal savings associations. We also supervise the federal branches and agencies of foreign banks. Our goal in supervising banks and federal savings associations is to ensure that they operate in a safe and sound manner and in compliance with laws requiring fair treatment of their customers and fair access to credit and financial products.
long_description:
The OCC's primary mission is to charter, regulate, and supervise all national banks and federal savings associations. We also supervise the federal branches and agencies of foreign banks. Our goal in supervising banks and federal savings associations is to ensure that they operate in a safe and sound manner and in compliance with laws requiring fair treatment of their customers and fair access to credit and financial products.

The OCC was established in 1863 as an independent bureau of the U.S. Department of the Treasury. The President, with the advice and consent of the U.S. Senate, appoints the Comptroller to head the agency for a five-year term. The Comptroller also is a director of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and NeighborWorks® America.

name: @USDA_FS_DPG
short_description: The mission of the USDA Forest Service is to sustain the health, diversity, and productivity of the Nation’s forests and grasslands to meet the needs of present and future generations.
long_description:
The Forest Service motto, "Caring for the Land and Serving People," captures the spirit of our mission, which we accomplish through five main activities:

 Protection and management of natural resources on National Forest System lands.

 Research on all aspects of forestry, rangeland management, and forest resource utilization.

 Community assistance and cooperation with State and local governments, forest industries, and private landowners to help protect and manage non-Federal forest and associated range and watershed lands to improve conditions in rural areas.

 Achieving and supporting an effective workforce that reflects the full range of diversity of the American people.

 International assistance in formulating policy and coordinating U.S. support for the protection and sound management of the world's forest resources.

name: USAID's Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
short_description: USAID's Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance saves lives on behalf of the American people.
long_description: USAID’s Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance (BHA) leads and coordinates the U.S. Government’s humanitarian assistance efforts overseas. Helping people affected by disasters is at the core of what BHA does every day, all over the world. The Bureau responds to an average of 75 disasters in more than 70 countries every year, ensuring that aid reaches people affected by natural disasters, including hurricanes, earthquakes, and volcanoes, as well as protracted crises, such as drought and conflict. We also support food insecure refugees fleeing war, violence, or persecution.

name: USAID's Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
short_description: USAID's Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance saves lives on behalf of the American people.
long_description: USAID’s Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance (BHA) leads and coordinates the U.S. Government’s humanitarian assistance efforts overseas. Helping people affected by disasters is at the core of what BHA does every day, all over the world. name: NOAA Earth System Research Laboratory
long_description: NOAA’s Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL) studies the Earth’s atmosphere and oceans to keep NOAA on the leading edge in its ability to serve the needs of our society. ESRL integrates these findings into environmental information products and methods to improve critical weather and climate tools used by the private sector, government agencies, decision-makers, and the public.

name: NOAA ESRL
short_description: The NOAA Earth System Research Laboratory: World-class climate, weather, and air quality research and information products for the nation.

name: NOAA ESRL
short_description: ESRL provides world-class climate, weather, and air quality research and information products for the nation.

name: NOAAESRL
long_description: NOAA's Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL) was formed to pursue a broad and comprehensive understanding of the Earth system. This system comprises many physical, chemical and biological processes that need to be dynamically integrated to better predict their behavior over scales from local to global and periods of minutes to millennia. We are located in Boulder, Colorado. For more information, visit us at: https://www.esrl.noaa.gov.

name: NOAA Hydrometeorology Testbed - HMT
short_description: The NOAA Hydrometeorology Testbed (HMT) conducts research on precipitation and weather conditions that can lead to flooding, and fosters transition of scientific advances and new tools into forecasting operations.

name: Careers at AOC
short_description: Employment opportunities at the Architect of the Capitol.
long_description: Serving Congress and the Supreme Court, the Architect of the Capitol (AOC) is the builder and steward of the landmark buildings and grounds of Capitol Hill. The AOC staff preserves and maintains the historic buildings, monuments, art and inspirational gardens on the Capitol campus. Recognizing the trust placed in us by Congress and the American people, the AOC team is committed to providing a safe environment and inspiring experiences for all who work and visit the symbol of American democracy.

name: NOAA Fisheries Southeast
short_description: This is the official Twitter feed for NOAA Fisheries Southeast. NOAA Fisheries is responsible for science-based conservation and management for sustainable living marine resources and healthy ecosystems. Website: https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/region/southeast
long_description: This is the official Twitter feed for NOAA Fisheries Southeast. NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service is the federal agency, a division of the Department of Commerce, responsible for the stewardship of the nation's living marine resources and their habitat. NOAA Fisheries is responsible for the management, conservation and protection of living marine resources. To do this, the agency assesses and predicts the status of fish stocks, ensures compliance with fisheries regulations, and works to reduce wasteful fishing practices. NOAA Fisheries also recovers protected marine species (i.e. whales, turtles), striking a balance with America's economic and recreational opportunities. With the help of the six regional offices and eight management councils, NOAA Fisheries Service works together with communities on a wide variety of fishery management issues, promotes sustainable fisheries, and works to end overfishing, and the decline of species and their habitat. Website: https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/region/southeast

name: NOAA Ocean Acidification Program
short_description: NOAA's Ocean Acidification Program seeks to better prepare society to respond to changing ocean conditions and resources by expanding understanding of ocean acidification, through interdisciplinary partnerships, nationally and internationally. Ocean acidification is occurring because our ocean is absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, leading to lower pH and greater acidity. This is causing a fundamental change in the chemistry of the ocean from pole to pole.
long_description: Through scientific research the NOAA Ocean Acidification Program is working to better understand and predict where and how fast ocean chemistry is changing along with its impacts to marine life, ecosystems and human communities. As outlined in the Federal Ocean Acidification Research and Monitoring Act this national program is mandated to educate the public about ocean acidification, its impacts and ways to adapt to this ocean change. This platform allows the program to educate the general public about scientific findings, opportunities and events to promote a science-informed and responsive society.

name: Western Area Power Administration
short_description: Our mission is to market and deliver clean, renewable, reliable, cost-based federal hydroelectric power and related services in our 15-state service area.
long_description: We're one of four power marketing administrations within the U.S. Department of Energy whose role is to market and transmit wholesale electricity from multi-use water projects. Our service area encompasses a 15-state region of the central and western U.S. where our more than 17,000 circuit mile transmission system carries electricity from 56 hydropower plants operated by the Bureau of Reclamation, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and the International Boundary and Water Commission. We also market power from the Navajo Generating Station coal-fired plant near Page, Ariz. Together, these plants have an installed capacity of 10,504 megawatts. We sell our power to preference customers such as Federal and state agencies, cities and towns, rural electric cooperatives, public utility districts, irrigation districts and Native American tribes. They, in turn, provide retail electric service to millions of consumers in the West. Shares and posts do not constitute endorsements.

name: Western Area Power Administration
short_description: Power marketing and transmission system operation and maintenance
long_description: WAPA's service territory covers 15 states in the West. The agency markets and delivers more than 10,000 megawatts of reliable, cost-based hydropower from powerplants at 56 Federal dams to rural electric cooperatives, municipalities, public utility districts, Federal and state agencies, Native American tribes and irrigation districts.

name: Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument
short_description: Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument and UNESCO World Heritage Site is the single largest conservation area under the U.S. flag, and one of the largest marine conservation areas in the world.
long_description: Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument and UNESCO World Heritage Site is the single largest conservation area under the U.S. flag, and one of the largest marine conservation areas in the world.

name: Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument
short_description: Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument is the single largest fully-protected conservation area   in the world. It encompasses 582,578 square miles of the Pacific Ocean (1,508,870 square kilometers) – an area nearly the size of the Gulf of Mexico.
long_description:
Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument is the single largest fully-protected conservation area 
 in the world. It encompasses 582,578 square miles of the Pacific Ocean (1,508,870 square kilometers) – an area nearly the size of the Gulf of Mexico. The Monument, created expressly to protect an exceptional array of natural and cultural resources, was established by Presidential Proclamation 8031 on June 15, 2006 and expanded by Presidential Proclamation 9478 on August 26, 2016 under the authority of the Antiquities Act (16 U.S.C. 431-433). It is the United States' only mixed (natural and cultural) UNESCO World Heritage Site, recogized for both its cultural and natural significance.

name: @USFSPlumas
short_description: Official page of the Plumas National Forest, which occupies 1,146,000 acres of scenic mountain lands in the northern Sierra Nevada.
long_description:
Situated in the Sierra Nevada, just south of the Cascade Range, the Plumas is versatile in its land features, uncrowded, and enhanced by a pleasant climate. Outdoor enthusiasts are attracted year round to its many streams and lakes, beautiful deep canyons, rich mountain valleys, meadows, and lofty peaks.

Beginning in the foothill country near Lake Oroville, the Plumas extends through heavily timbered slopes and into the rugged high country near U.S. Highway 395. State Highway 70 between Oroville and U.S. Highway 395 provides year round access, and State Highway 89 provides convenient connections through Tahoe.

name: @clevelandnf
short_description: Official page of the Cleveland National Forest, which is the southern-most National Forest in California. Consisting of 460,000 acres, the forest offers a wide variety of terrains and recreational opportunities.
long_description: Until the arrival in San Diego of Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo, the lands now within the Cleveland National Forest were known only to the desert and coastal Indian tribes who used them. The Kumeyaay, Luiseños, Cahuilla and Cupeño found a good living on the abundant acorns and game. Many of our trails today follow those routes first used by these early dwellers.

name: @EldoradoNF
short_description: Official page of the Eldorado National Forest, which is situated near the original California gold discovery site on the American River at Coloma, and still boasts numerous gold-bearing rivers and streams.
long_description: The Eldorado National Forest is located in the central Sierra Nevada. Portions of Alpine, Amador, El Dorado, and Placer counties lie within the Forest Boundary. The forest is bordered on the north by the Tahoe National Forest, on the east by the Lake Tahoe Basin Management Unit, on the southeast by the Humboldt-Toiyabe, and to the south by the Stanislaus National Forest.

name: @InyoNF
short_description: Official page of the Inyo National Forest, which extends 165 miles near the California and Nevada border. It covers about 2 million acres, mostly on the eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada.
long_description: Approximately one million acres are in nine Congressionally-designated Wilderness Areas. Elevations range from 4,000’ in the Owens Valley to 14,494’ at Mt. Whitney, the highest peak in the contiguous United States. Recreational opportunities include camping, picnicking, hiking, fishing, equestrian use, and off-highway vehicle use. Ski resorts offer alpine skiing and snowboarding; over 100 miles of trails groomed for multiple purpose winter use (snowmobile, ski, and snowshoe), and approximately 45 miles of trails groomed for cross-country skiing.

name: @KlamathNF
short_description: Official page of the Klamath National Forest, which covers an area of 1,700,000 acres located in Siskiyou County, Northern California and Jackson County, Oregon.
long_description:
The forest includes five wilderness areas, Marble Mountain, Russian Wilderness Area, Trinity Alps, Red Buttes Wilderness Area and Siskiyou Wilderness Area.

In the lower elevations, you'll find park-like stands of Ponderosa Pines, while in the higher elevations, the Douglas fir, sub-alpine fir and mixed conifer stands beg to be explored.

There are 200 miles of river system for rafting and 152 miles of wild and scenic rivers in the forest.  In addition, Klamath National Forest offers grazing and timber opportunities as well as 34 campgrounds, hiking, fishing and wildlife viewing.
